channel.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
channel.description:
[size=14pt][b]Table of Contents[/b][/size]
[ul][li][iurl=#BYTE]Byte[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#SHORT]Short[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#INT]Int[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#LONG]Long[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#FLOAT]Float[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#DOUBLE]Double[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#BOOLEAN]Boolean[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#CHAR]Char[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#STRING]String[/iurl][/li]
[li][iurl=#HOWTO]How to Call Each Variable[/iurl][/li][/ul]
[center][size=14pt][b][u]Basic Data Types[/u][/b][/size][/center]
[center][b]The Java programming language is statically-typed, which means that all variables must first be declared before they can be used. Each variable uses a certain amount of memory. Overuse of memory can cause a crash of the java application. So by removing any unused variables, meaning that they might be declared, but not being used, will lower the amount of memory usage the java application uses. The amount of memory used are measured in Bytes.
*NOTE: Please do know that I did take definitions from the Primitive Data Types document from Oracle. I simply have removed some lines from each definition to make it more simple for people to read and understand. The original document can be found [url=http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/datatypes.html]Here[/url].[/b][/center]
[ANCHOR=BYTE][b][u]Byte[/u][/b]
[b]Definition -[/b] It has a minimum value of -128 and a maximum value of 127. The byte data type can be useful for saving memory in large arrays, where the memory savings actually matters. They can also be used in place of int where their limits help to clarify your code.
Bytes Used: 1
Example of a Byte in a Private Server: [code=java]public byte poisonMask = 0;[/code]
[ANCHOR=SHORT][b][u]Short[/u][/b]
[b]Definition[/b] - It has a minimum value of -32,768 and a maximum value of 32,767. As with byte, the same guidelines apply: you can use a short to save memory in large arrays, in situations where the memory savings actually matters.
[b]Bytes Used:[/b] 2
[b]Example of a Short in a Private Server:[/b] [code=java]public short readShort() { return (short) ((short) ((pData[caret++] & 0xff) << 8) | (short) (pData[caret++] & 0xff)); }[/code]
This is just an example of how a short is being used to hold and read packet information for a basic Packet Handling System.
[ANCHOR=INT][b][u]Int[/u][/b]
[b]Definition[/b] - It has a minimum value of -2,147,483,648 and a maximum value of 2,147,483,647. For integral values, this data type is generally the default choice unless there is a reason (like the above) to choose something else. This data type will most likely be large enough for the numbers your program will use, but if you need a wider range of values, use long instead. You can't use decimals using Ints as Ints use the value of 1. These shouldn't be used in any algorithm as the numbers will automatically rounded and you won't get the exact number. Doubles are the best variable to use for Algorithms.
[b]Bytes Used:[/b] 2
[b]Example of an Int in a Private Server:[/b] As you can see, the minimum and maximum values of an int are positive and negative 2,137,483,647. As most of you know, that is the max stack for any stack able item in RuneScape. There is a bug in some Private Servers where you could crash the server by taking a max cash stack and dieing with it in the wilderness. The simple fix for that is going to Config.Java (In most servers), and where you find the line [code=java]public static final int MAXITEM_AMOUNT = [/code] and adding [code=java]Integer.MAX_VALUE;[/code] which tells the int to call for the maximum value.
[ANCHOR=LONG][b][u]Long[/u][/b]
[b]Definition -[/b] It has a minimum value of -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 and a maximum value of 9,223,372,036,854,775,807. Use this data type when you need a range of values wider than those provided by int.
[b]Bytes Used:[/b] 8
[b]Example of a Long in a Private Server:[/b] [code=java]for (final long friend : c.friends) { if ((friend != 0) && (friend == friendToAdd)) { canAdd = false; c.sendMessage(friendToAdd + " is already on your friends list."); } }[/code] This snippet is using a long to loop through a player's friend list to check if the string being inputted already exists or not, and if the string inputted already exists then to send the message [code=java] c.sendMessage(friendToAdd + " is already on your friends list.");[/code]
[ANCHOR=FLOAT][b][u]Float[/u][/b]
[b]Definition -[/b]Its range of values is beyond the scope of this discussion, but is specified in the Floating-Point Types, Formats, and Values section of the Java Language Specification. As with the recommendations for byte and short, use a float (instead of double) if you need to save memory in large arrays of floating point numbers. This data type should never be used for precise values, such as currency. For that, you will need to use the java.math.BigDecimal class instead. Numbers and Strings covers BigDecimal and other useful classes provided by the Java platform.
[b]Bytes Used:[/b] 4
[b]Example of a Float being used in a Private Server:[/b] [code=java]private static final float[][] aFloatArrayArray669 = new float[2][8];[/code] This float is being used to store information as a 2D Array. As floats have a range of values, you can't declare [code=java]Integer.MAX_VALUE[/code]
[ANCHOR=DOUBLE][b][u]Double[/u][/b]
[b]Definition -[/b] Its range of values is beyond the scope of this discussion, but is specified in the Floating-Point Types, Formats, and Values section of the Java Language Specification. For decimal values, this data type is generally the default choice. As mentioned above, this data type should never be used for precise values, such as currency.
[b]Bytes Used:[/b] 8
[b]Example of a Double being used in a Private Server[/b] [code=java]double currentTileXCount = 0.0; double currentTileYCount = 0.0;[/code] You can see that the variable equals a decimal value, 0.0. As the value is 0.0 by default, these variables can be given temporary values. These two doubles are used in an algorithm to find the current X and Y coordinates of the character in game.
[ANCHOR=BOOLEAN][b][u]Boolean[/u][/b]
[b]Definition -[/b] The boolean data type has only two possible values: true and false. Use this data type for simple flags that track true/false conditions. This data type represents one bit of information, but its "size" isn't something that's precisely defined.
[b]Bytes Used:[/b] 1 or 4 (Usually)
[b]Example of a Boolean being used in a Private Server.[/b] [code=java]public boolean canChangeAppearance = false;[/code] As you can see, the condition of this boolean is false. By default, it is false until it is changed from another location to true.
[ANCHOR=CHAR][b][u]Char[/u][/b]
[b]Definition -[/b] It has a minimum value of '\u0000' (or 0) and a maximum value of '\uffff' (or 65,535).
FYI - The most common memory leaks are Char[] leaks, meaning that there are a lot of unused declared char variables within the common private server. Again, this can be fixed by commenting out any unused char variables or deleting if they will never be used again.
[b]Example of a Char in a Private Server[/b] [code=java]final char first = name.charAt(0);[/code]
[ANCHOR=STRING][b][u]String[/u][/b]
[b]Definition -[/b] The Java programming language also provides special support for character strings via the java.lang.String class. Enclosing your character string within double quotes will automatically create a new String object; for example, String s = "this is a string";. String objects are immutable, which means that once created, their values cannot be changed. It is not a Primitive Data Type, but is it's own class.
[b]Bytes Used:[/b] 4
[b]Example of a String being used in a Private Server[/b] [code=java]public static final String SERVER_NAME = "Server Name";[/code] This string can be called from another class by importing the class where the string is declared, and putting [code=java]Config.SERVER_NAME[/code]
[ANCHOR=HOWTO][center][size=14pt][b][u]How to Call Each Variable[/u][/b][/size][/center]
[center][b]Now some of you may be wondering, "What does static mean? What does final mean? Whats the difference between Private and Public?" Well all of these variables are called through certain ways.[/center]
[b]private[/b] - Means that that variable can only be called within that same class.
Example: [code=java]private int exampleHere = 1;[/code]
[b]public[/b] - Means that that variable can be called from anywhere within the source folder. As long as the certain class is imported, you are able to use the variable.
Example: [code=java]public int exampleHere = 1;[/code]
[b]static[/b] - Can be applied to one of three things: variables, methods, and static nested classes
When applied to variables it means that the variable is shared among all instances of the class When applied to methods it means that the method can be accessed directly, without the need to instance that object. When applied to static nested classes it means that you cannot access instance variables of the enclosing class.
[b]Thanks to AtomicInt_ for Clarifying[/b]
Example: [code=java]private static exampleHere = 1;[/code]
[b]final[/b] - Means that the variable can only be assigned ONCE if the final variable is without a value then you are required to construct it to initialize it, if the variable is a final parameter it means that the variable cannot be changed after initialization of that variable.
Example: [code=java]public final int exampleHere = 1;[/code]
[b]Thanks to AtomicInt_ for Clarifying this aswell[/b]

item.description:

The Java docs don’t explain primitive data types well enough already?
[/quote]
At least they’re correct…
A string can be changed after it’s given it’a first value…[/quote]

Strings are immutable in Java.

item.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

[quote=“ranger squad, post:13, topic:460738”][quote author=Jmood link=topic=563673.msg4107667#msg4107667 date=1348176856]
The Java docs don’t explain primitive data types well enough already?
[/quote]
At least they’re correct…
A string can be changed after it’s given it’a first value. It also uses 4 bytes per character. The way that you merely added Atomic’s explanation to the end of “yours” shows this as a copy and paste job. If you’re going to make a tutorial, make it right! People reading it should be able to safely assume that you know what you are talking about and that what you have written is correct.[/quote]
no it can’t, a string reference can be given a new string object but the string object itself is immutable. a char is only 2 bytes and the only case where it would be treated as anything more is on the stack.

Read full topic

item.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:22, topic:460738”]‘static’ can be applied to one of three things: variables, methods, and static nested classes

when applied to variables it means that the variable is shared among all instances of the class
when applied to methods it means that the method can be accessed directly, without the need to instance that object.
when applied to static nested classes it means that you cannot access instance variables of the enclosing class.

‘final’ means that the variable can only be assigned ONCE if the final variable is without a value then you are required to construct it to initialize it, if the variable is a final parameter it means that the variable cannot be changed after initialization of that variable.[/quote]Thanks Ryley. I fixed up the definitions and gave you credits.

Read full topic
item.source: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies

item.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

‘static’ can be applied to one of three things: variables, methods, and static nested classes

when applied to variables it means that the variable is shared among all instances of the class
when applied to methods it means that the method can be accessed directly, without the need to instance that object.
when applied to static nested classes it means that you cannot access instance variables of the enclosing class.

‘final’ means that the variable can only be assigned ONCE if the final variable is without a value then you are required to construct it to initialize it, if the variable is a final parameter it means that the variable cannot be changed after initialization of that variable.

Read full topic
item.source: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies

item.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:20, topic:460738”]* Double’s length is 8 bytes… it’s a 64 bit representation.

  • String’s underlying length is equal to its character amount + 1 (null character \0) – or maybe it’s string length + payload… the first one is C’s way.
  • Boolean doesn’t have a standard size; it’s usually 1 or 4 iirc.
  • Your definition of static is bad/incorrect
  • Your definition of final is meh
  • You should never really use a short unless it’s within a buffer

I’m glad you tried to contribute and what not, but please … don’t spread misinformation/confusion.[/quote]Ok. This was part of the goal of the thread. To have people correct my mistakes so I can learn and change it to the correct thing.

Could you please provide me with a definition of statis and final?

Read full topic
item.source: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies

item.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

  • Double’s length is 8 bytes… it’s a 64 bit representation.
  • String’s underlying length is equal to its character amount + 1 (null character \0) – or maybe it’s string length + payload… the first one is C’s way.
  • Boolean doesn’t have a standard size; it’s usually 1 or 4 iirc.
  • Your definition of static is bad/incorrect
  • Your definition of final is meh
  • You should never really use a short unless it’s within a buffer

I’m glad you tried to contribute and what not, but please … don’t spread misinformation/confusion.

Read full topic
item.source: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies

item.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“Jmood, post:15, topic:460738”][19:48:18] <super_> please
[19:48:21] <super_> delete taht thread
[19:48:23] <super_> someone
[19:48:24] <super_> it hurts

This is the only thing I can say for this thread. We already have a resource that explains primitive data types well enough for even a beginner and wait there’s more!

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/datatypes.html

look at that nuts and bolts for the beginners![/quote]The purpose of this thread is help new programmers learn. I also included a link to the original tutorial from Oracle if they want to get more into depth. I don’t care if the more advanced programmers hate this, it explains the basics and that’s the purpose. As for Super_, I respect him, but he doesn’t have the right to request a deletion on this thread just because he doesn’t like it.

Read full topic

item.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“ranger squad, post:13, topic:460738”][quote author=Jmood link=topic=563673.msg4107667#msg4107667 date=1348176856]
The Java docs don’t explain primitive data types well enough already?
[/quote]
At least they’re correct…
A string can be changed after it’s given it’a first value. It also uses 4 bytes per character. The way that you merely added Atomic’s explanation to the end of “yours” shows this as a copy and paste job. If you’re going to make a tutorial, make it right! People reading it should be able to safely assume that you know what you are talking about and that what you have written is correct.[/quote]The fact that all you can do is assume somebody who proved you wrong has a “genetic disability” is what is sad. AtomicInt_ explained it to me, so I put it there so people can know truly what a string is. This is for learning, not dissing.

Read full topic

item.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

Also,

static - Static variables are initialized only once , at the start of the execution. These variables will be initialized first, before the initialization of any instance variables.

This is also false, statically declared variables can be changed as many times as you want; unless it has the final declaration. Static variables just means you don’t need a object of it’s class to access it’s value, in layman’s terms. Also, static values are also declared as ‘lazy’, in other languages, which means they aren’t initialized until they are called.

Read full topic
item.source: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies

item.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:9, topic:460738”][quote author=RiiPiiNFtW link=topic=563673.msg4107492#msg4107492 date=1348165423]

a string is not a primitive type, it’s a class.
[/quote]It is a class itself, but is used as a primitive type.

No, the primitive data types are: byte, short, int, long, float, double, boolean and char

Java allows a string literal as an expression of type String, though.[/quote]Oh, Ok. I learned something new. Guess ill edit that bit.

Read full topic
item.source: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies

item.title: Explanation of Primitive Data Types for Newbies
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“RiiPiiNFtW, post:8, topic:460738”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=563673.msg4107490#msg4107490 date=1348165212]
a string is not a primitive type, it’s a class.
[/quote]It is a class itself, but is used as a primitive type.[/quote]

No, the primitive data types are: byte, short, int, long, float, double, boolean and char

Java allows a string literal as an expression of type String, though.
